III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
1

perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 12/14/24, a youth was locked out of the facility or not allowed
back in without shoes or a jacket on. Youth then left and walked
the road until a stranger picked the youth up. Youth was taken to
the police department. Staff followed the vehicle, but did not stop
the youth from walking along the road, crossing a busy highway,
or the stranger from picking the youth up. The stranger contacted
the police before the facility did. This is not the first time an
incident like this has occurred with the facility
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Law Enforcement (LE) was interviewed via phone on 1/10/25.
LE reported the original call that came in was from the strangers
who picked Youth A up. LE reported the strangers stated they
found a girl walking by herself with no shoes or jacket, and they
were bringing her to the police department. LE reported a few
minutes later, one of the facility’s staff (couldn’t remember her
name) called and said Youth A got into a stranger’s car and she
was following the stranger’s vehicle. LE reported both cars pulled
into the police department, and she went to speak to the facility
staff. LE reported the facility staff didn’t check on Youth A right
away and Youth A remained in the stranger’s car. LE talked to
Youth A and Youth A reported the facility staff allowed her to walk
away, and she didn’t want to go back to the facility.
Youth A was interviewed via phone on 12/17/25 in
coordination with MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported she was in
between the two doors (staff office door and main door) in the
entryway of the facility. Youth A reported she was irritated
because she wasn’t allowed to play her instrument, so she tried to
break into the staff office door to get her instrument. Youth A
reported her instrument is one of her coping skills and she felt
staff weren’t listening to her. Youth A reported she walked out the
front door of the facility. Youth A reported she turned around,
knocked on the door of the facility, and wasn’t let back in. She
then stated she was knocking on the door in the entryway, before
she walked outside, and they (Youth A couldn’t remember which
staff) wouldn’t let her in. Youth A reported she was banging on it
hard, and staff left her out there. Youth A reported since they
wouldn’t let her into the facility, she chose to run away. Youth A
reported she sat on the playset outside of the facility for a while,
but then she started walking away from the facility because she
was cold. Youth A reported when she walked away from the
2

facility, Staff 1 began to follow her in the facility van. Youth A
reported she got to the end of the road and walked across the
highway. Youth A reported she stopped a car on the highway, saw
it was an elderly couple, and got into their car. Youth A reported
when she got into their car, she saw Staff 1 in the facility van
across the highway. Youth A reported she didn’t want to go back
to the facility, so the couple took her to the police station. Youth A
reported right after they pulled into the police station, Staff 1 and
Staff 3 also pulled in. Youth A reported Staff 3 spoke with LE.
Youth A reported she ran out of the facility three times that day,
but the first two times, staff followed her, and she returned to the
facility. Youth A reported she eventually got into the facility van
with Staff 1 and went back to the facility after she spoke with LE.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 1/10/25 in coordination
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported Youth A was trying to
break into the staff office door from inside the main area of the
facility for about 15 minutes in the morning, but then gave up. Staff
1 reported around lunchtime, Youth A began trying to break into
the staff office again. When she was unsuccessful, Youth A
walked out of the main door into the entryway of the facility to try
and break into the other staff office door. Staff 1 reported she was
initially making lunch, but when she saw Youth A walk out, she
went to assist. Staff 1 reported she and Staff 2 tried to redirect
Youth A and asked her to come back into the facility, but she
refused. Staff 1 reported she was talking to Youth A through the
main door of the facility while Staff 2 was talking to Youth A from
the staff office door. Staff 1 reported no staff went into the
entryway to talk to Youth A face-to-face, but she couldn’t explain
why. Staff 1 reported she didn’t leave the door cracked to talk to
Youth A because she didn’t want other youth getting involved in
the situation. Staff 1 reported Youth A banged on the door, and
when Staff 1 opened it, Youth A said, “fuck off”, walked out the
front door to go outside and began walking away. Staff 1 reported
she grabbed the van keys and began following Youth A. Staff 1
reported Youth A began cutting through neighbor’s yards, so Staff
1 tried to keep an eye on her in the yards while she was driving
down the road. Staff 1 reported there is a wooded area through
one neighbor’s yard, and it meets up with the highway. Staff 1
reported Youth A went through the wooded area and went the
opposite way down the highway. Staff 1 reported it’s a divided
highway, and she was unable to follow Youth A in the van
because it was a one-way street. Staff 1 reported she turned right,
and then used the U-turn Lane to go into the opposite direction
and continue to follow Youth A. Staff 1 reported she saw Youth A
get into a stranger’s van, so she followed the van. Staff 1 reported
3

she called Staff 2 and asked Staff 2 to call the police to let them
know what happened. Staff 1 continued to follow the stranger’s
van, and they pulled into the police station. Staff 1 reported Staff 3
met them at the police station. Staff 1 reported she and Staff 3
tried to get Youth A to get in the facility van, but Youth A refused.
Staff 1 reported LE eventually convinced Youth A to get into the
van and go back to the facility. Staff 1 reported Youth A never
banged on the door to the facility requesting to be let in. Staff 1
reported Youth A was never locked out of the house with no ability
to re-enter. Staff 1 reported the side door of the facility is left
unlocked during the day, and Youth A could have entered the
facility on her own at any time. Staff 1 reported Youth A is aware
of this information because she’s used it multiple times when she
has gone outside before.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 1/9/25 in
coordination with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported she was in
the staff office documenting medication distribution for the youth.
Staff 2 reported Youth A was trying to break into the staff office
from the entryway to the facility. Staff 2 reported she was standing
at the door and talking to Youth A through the door and looking at
her through the blinds on the window. Staff 2 reported she told
Youth A she could use her instrument later but could not right now
because another youth was in crisis. Staff 2 offered Youth A other
options she could do instead. Staff 2 reported she didn’t go into
the entryway to talk to Youth A face-to-face because if she
opened the staff office door, Youth A would have gained entry.
Staff 2 reported she remained in the staff office because, if Youth
A was successful in breaking the staff office door, Youth A would
have had access to unsafe items from the staff office. Staff 2
reported Staff 1 was handling the situation from the other door.
Staff 2 reported Staff 1 opened the door and asked Youth A to
come back inside, but Youth A refused. Staff 2 reported she
reminded Youth A she could use her instrument later, but Youth A
didn’t accept that information and said she wanted her instrument
immediately. Staff 2 reported Youth A exited the facility and went
outside. Staff 2 reported after Youth A walked out, Staff 2 made
sure the side door to the facility was unlocked, so Youth A could
come back inside whenever she wanted. Staff 2 reported Youth A
never banged on the staff office door or the main door asking for
re-entry. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 followed Youth A and called
shortly later to tell Staff 2 Youth A got into a stranger’s vehicle.
Staff 2 reported she called the police to inform them what
happened, and she was still on the phone with the police when
Staff 1 and Youth A arrived at the police station. Staff 2 reported
4

Staff 1 immediately followed Youth A when Youth A left the facility,
which is what their AWOL protocol says to do.
Staff 3 was interviewed via video conference on 1/10/25 in
coordination with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3 reported she was
either in the bedroom hallway or in the laundry room when Youth
A walked out of the facility. Staff 3 reported she found out Youth A
left when Staff 1 grabbed the van keys and said she was following
Youth A up the road. Shortly after, Staff 1 called Staff 3 and asked
if she could meet them. Staff 3 reported Staff 1 told her Youth A
got into a car with a couple of strangers. Staff 3 got into her car,
followed them, and met them at the police station. Staff 3 reported
5-10 minutes after arriving, LE arrived and they all discussed the
situation. Staff 3 reported Youth A agreed to go back to the facility,
so Youth A got into the van with Staff 1, and they went back. Staff
3 reported she can typically reason with and talk to Youth A better
than some other staff, so she didn’t understand why the other staff
didn’t reach out to her sooner to ask for assistance.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
1/9/25 in coordination with MDHHS Worker. Supervisor
reported he was not present at the time of the incident, but he was
on call and was called in because Youth A was upset. Supervisor
reported when he arrived at the facility, he was informed Youth A
got into a car with strangers. Supervisor reported soon after,
Youth A came back and walked into the side door of the facility.
Supervisor reported he met with her, processed her coping skills,
and they developed a plan for how to handle things if she became
upset again. Supervisor reported if a youth leaves the facility, staff
are to follow them as much as they can, and they should call
police if it becomes a dangerous situation. Supervisor reported
staff would not have been able to restrain a youth in this situation
because she was not trying to harm herself or others, and going
AWOL is not a sufficient reason to restrain a youth. Supervisor
reported he feels staff should have called the police sooner than
they did.
VIDEO REVIEWED:
Video footage from 12/14/24 was reviewed from two angles. The
first angle is from the entryway to the facility. Youth A is seen in
the entryway trying to break into the staff office door. She is
throwing her shoulder against it, kicking it, and pushing it. She has
something in her hand, but it isn’t clear what it is. There are no
staff in the entryway with her. She begins touching the main door,
but it is unknown what she is doing to the door because her body
is blocking the camera angle. She put her hand on the handle and
5

stands there, switches back to the staff office door, and back to
the main door. Then she walks out the front door leading outside.
At no point does Youth A knock or bang on the door. Since there
is no audio on the video, no conversations between Youth A and
staff can be heard.
The second angle is from outside and shows the front door of the
facility. Youth A exits the facility and begins walking towards the
road. Staff 2 immediately opens the front door, sees Youth A, and
closes the front door. A couple minutes later, the facility van is
seen driving down the road in the same direction Youth A was
walking.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• MiSACWIS Incident Report dated 12/14/24 authored by
Chief Administrator states Youth A wanted to play her
instrument, and staff told her not right now because there
was another youth in crisis. Youth A became upset and
attempted to use some silverware to break into the staff
office. When it didn’t work, Youth A began yelling and
banging on the door in the lobby area. Staff (unspecified)
asked Youth A to put the silverware down and make safe
choices, but Youth A ignored staff and went outside. Youth
A ran towards the highway, running through neighbor’s
yards, and Staff 1 followed Youth A in the van. Youth A got
inside a stranger’s vehicle, and Staff 1 followed them. Staff
1 asked Staff 2 to call the police, so Staff 2 did. Staff 1 and
the strangers pulled into the police station. Youth A refused
to go with Staff 1 until police arrived and convinced her.
• Adrian Police Department police report #240013956 states
LE was dispatched in reference to a caller who said they
had a youth in their van who was walking on the side of the
road with no shoes or jacket. While enroute, dispatch
advised they received a call from staff at the facility stating
Youth A ran away and got into a stranger’s vehicle, which
they were following. LE met with everyone in the police
station’s parking lot. Youth A told LE staff locked her out of
the house and would not let her back in, so she walked
away.
• Incident Reporting policy states if a youth leaves the
premises, staff will search the area and/or maintain
supervision at a safe distance. If a youth cannot be located
for more than 5 minutes, law enforcement will be notified
and a missing person report filed.
6

• Supervision Guidelines state visual supervision will be
maintained while in the community unless otherwise
specified. While in the general areas of the home, staff will
provide visual supervision to ensure safety.
• Staff 1 does not have any disciplinary records in her
employee file. Staff 1 completed policies and procedures
training (5/15/24) as well as supervision requirements
training (10/22/24).
• Staff 2 does not have any disciplinary records in her
employee file. Staff 2 completed supervision requirements
training on 10/22/24.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance based on interviews conducted
and documentation reviewed. Youth A had an ability to get into the
facility through the unlocked side door, which she has utilized
before when she’s been outside. However, she chose to go
AWOL instead. As soon as Youth A walked away from the facility,
staff followed her and continued to follow her even after Youth A
entered the stranger’s vehicle. Staff maintained visual supervision
for Youth A and followed AWOL procedures.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
If a youth is in the entryway and in distress, staff should ensure
they go into the entryway with the youth to provide support face-
to-face instead of talking to the youth through the doors of the
facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
